chapters.introduction: Physics is the branch of science that deals with the study of matter, energy, motion, force, and their interactions. This chapter introduces physics as a fundamental discipline and emphasises the importance of measurement.

scope_of_physics.description: Physics explains natural phenomena using laws and principles

strong_nuclear_force.example: Binding of protons and neutrons in nucleus

measurement_of_length.least_count: Smallest measurement an instrument can take

error_calculations.absolute_error: Difference between measured value and true value
error_calculations.relative_error: Absolute error divided by mean value

rules: Zeros between non-zero digits are significant
Trailing zeros without decimal are not significant

chapters.one_liner: Accurate measurement is the foundation of all physical laws.

chapters.introduction: Kinematics deals with the description of motion without considering the forces that cause it.

motion.definition: Change in position of an object with time

distance_and_displacement.displacement: Shortest straight-line distance between initial and final position

projectile_motion.definition: Motion of an object projected under gravity

uniform_circular_motion.definition: Motion with constant speed along a circular path

chapters.one_liner: Kinematics describes motion before forces explain it.

chapters.introduction: This chapter explains how forces affect the motion of objects and lays the foundation of classical mechanics.

force.definition: An interaction that can change the state of rest, motion, or shape of an object

first_law.statement: An object remains at rest or in uniform motion unless acted upon by an external force

second_law.statement: Rate of change of momentum is directly proportional to the applied force

third_law.statement: For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction

conservation_of_momentum.statement: Total momentum of a system remains constant if no external force acts

friction.definition: Force that opposes relative motion between two surfaces in contact

chapters.one_liner: Laws of motion connect force with observable movement.

chapters.introduction: This chapter explains how forces transfer energy and how work and power quantify this transfer.

work.definition: Work is done when a force produces displacement

work_energy_theorem.statement: Work done by a force equals the change in kinetic energy

law_of_conservation_of_energy.statement: Energy can neither be created nor destroyed, only transformed

chapters.one_liner: Energy explains motion without tracking every force.

chapters.chapter_name: Motion of System of Particles and Rigid Body
chapters.introduction: This chapter extends the laws of motion to systems of particles and rotating rigid bodies, introducing rotational mechanics.

system_of_particles.definition: A collection of particles considered together for analysis

centre_of_mass.definition: A point that represents the average position of mass of a system

motion_of_centre_of_mass.statement: Centre of mass moves as if all external forces act on it

rigid_body.definition: A body in which distance between any two points remains constant

radius_of_gyration.definition: Distance from axis where entire mass can be assumed concentrated

angular_momentum.definition: Product of moment of inertia and angular velocity
angular_momentum.conservation: Angular momentum remains constant if no external torque acts

chapters.one_liner: Rotation adds a new dimension to motion.

chapters.introduction: This chapter explains gravitational interaction between masses and its applications in planetary motion and satellites.

universal_law_of_gravitation.statement: Every mass attracts every other mass with a force proportional to the product of their masses and inversely proportional to the square of distance between them

acceleration_due_to_gravity.definition: Acceleration of a freely falling body due to Earth's gravity

escape_velocity.definition: Minimum velocity needed to escape Earth's gravitational field

chapters.one_liner: Gravitation governs motion from apples to planets.

chapters.introduction: This chapter studies the mechanical properties of solids, liquids, and gases and explains how matter responds to applied forces.

elasticity.definition: Property of a material by which it regains its original shape after removal of deforming force

strain.definition: Ratio of change in dimension to original dimension

hookes_law.statement: Stress is proportional to strain within elastic limit

elastic_moduli.youngs_modulus: Ratio of longitudinal stress to longitudinal strain
elastic_moduli.bulk_modulus: Ratio of volumetric stress to volumetric strain
elastic_moduli.shear_modulus: Ratio of shear stress to shear strain

viscosity.definition: Property of fluids that resists relative motion between layers

coefficient_of_viscosity.definition: Measure of fluid resistance to flow

terminal_velocity.definition: Maximum constant velocity attained by a body falling through a fluid

surface_tension.definition: Force per unit length acting along the surface of a liquid

capillarity.definition: Rise or fall of liquid in a narrow tube

chapters.one_liner: Bulk matter reveals how materials resist and respond to forces.

chapters.introduction: Thermodynamics deals with heat, work, and energy transfer and establishes laws governing thermal processes.

zeroth_law.statement: If two systems are in thermal equilibrium with a third system, they are in thermal equilibrium with each other

first_law.statement: Heat supplied equals change in internal energy plus work done

statements: Heat cannot spontaneously flow from colder to hotter body

entropy.definition: Measure of disorder of a system

heat_engines.definition: Device that converts heat into work

efficiency.definition: Ratio of work output to heat input

refrigerator.definition: Device that removes heat from a cold body

chapters.one_liner: Thermodynamics governs how energy flows and limits what is possible.

chapters.chapter_name: Behaviour of Perfect Gas and Kinetic Theory
chapters.introduction: This chapter explains the macroscopic behavior of gases using microscopic molecular motion through kinetic theory.

perfect_gas.definition: A hypothetical gas whose molecules occupy negligible volume and exert no intermolecular forces

boyles_law.statement: At constant temperature, pressure is inversely proportional to volume

charles_law.statement: At constant pressure, volume is directly proportional to temperature

gay_lussacs_law.statement: At constant volume, pressure is directly proportional to temperature

postulates: Gas molecules are in continuous random motion
Average kinetic energy depends only on temperature

degrees_of_freedom.definition: Number of independent ways in which a molecule can move

law_of_equipartition_of_energy.statement: Energy is equally distributed among all degrees of freedom

chapters.one_liner: Gas laws become meaningful when molecules start moving.

chapters.introduction: This chapter studies periodic motion and wave propagation, fundamental to sound, light, and quantum physics.

oscillatory_motion.definition: Motion that repeats itself at regular intervals

simple_harmonic_motion.definition: Oscillatory motion where restoring force is proportional to displacement

time_period.definition: Time taken to complete one oscillation

wave_motion.definition: Transfer of energy without transfer of matter

doppler_effect.definition: Change in frequency due to relative motion between source and observer

chapters.one_liner: Oscillations repeat, waves travel.

chapters.introduction: This chapter lays the quantitative foundation of chemistry by introducing the mole concept, laws of chemical combination, and stoichiometric calculations.

nature_of_matter.definition: Matter is anything that has mass and occupies space

law_of_conservation_of_mass.statement: Mass is neither created nor destroyed in a chemical reaction

law_of_constant_proportions.statement: A compound always contains the same elements in the same proportion by mass
law_of_constant_proportions.example: Water always has hydrogen and oxygen in 1:8 ratio

atomic_and_molecular_masses.atomic_mass: Average mass of an atom relative to 1/12th mass of carbon-12
atomic_and_molecular_masses.molecular_mass: Sum of atomic masses of atoms in a molecule
atomic_and_molecular_masses.formula_mass: Sum of atomic masses in an ionic compound

stoichiometry.definition: Calculation of quantities of reactants and products in a chemical reaction
stoichiometry.balanced_equation: Equation with equal number of atoms on both sides

chapters.one_liner: Chemistry becomes predictable when quantities are measured.

chapters.introduction: This chapter explains the internal structure of atoms and the development of atomic models to explain atomic behavior.

rutherfords_model.description: Atom has a dense positively charged nucleus

quantum_mechanical_model.heisenberg_uncertainty_principle: Position and momentum cannot be known simultaneously
quantum_mechanical_model.schrodinger_wave_equation: Describes behavior of electrons as waves

electronic_configuration.aufbau_principle: Electrons fill lower energy orbitals first
electronic_configuration.pauli_exclusion_principle: No two electrons have same four quantum numbers

chapters.one_liner: Atomic structure explains why elements behave differently.

chapters.chapter_name: Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties
chapters.introduction: This chapter explains how elements are systematically arranged in the periodic table and how their physical and chemical properties show periodic trends.

need_for_classification.reason: Large number of elements require systematic study

dobereiners_triads.idea: Groups of three elements with similar properties
dobereiners_triads.limitation: Applicable to only a few elements

newlands_law_of_octaves.statement: Every eighth element has similar properties

modern_periodic_table.modern_periodic_law: Properties of elements are periodic functions of their atomic numbers

electronic_configuration_and_periodicity.relationship: Properties depend on valence shell electronic configuration

ionization_enthalpy.definition: Energy required to remove an electron

electron_gain_enthalpy.definition: Energy released when an electron is added

electronegativity.definition: Ability of an atom to attract electrons

chapters.one_liner: The periodic table is the map of chemistry.

chapters.introduction: This chapter explains how and why atoms combine to form molecules and the shapes these molecules adopt.

chemical_bond.definition: Force that holds atoms together in a molecule

ionic_bonding.definition: Bond formed by transfer of electrons

lattice_energy.definition: Energy released when gaseous ions form solid crystal

covalent_bonding.definition: Bond formed by sharing of electrons

lewis_structure.definition: Representation of valence electrons using dots
lewis_structure.octet_rule: Atoms tend to complete eight electrons in valence shell

vsepr_theory.principle: Electron pairs repel each other and arrange to minimize repulsion

hybridisation.definition: Mixing of atomic orbitals to form new hybrid orbitals

molecular_orbital_theory.concept: Atomic orbitals combine to form molecular orbitals

bond_order.definition: Half the difference between bonding and antibonding electrons

hydrogen_bonding.definition: Attractive force between hydrogen and highly electronegative atom

chapters.one_liner: Chemical bonding explains why matter exists as it does.

chapters.introduction: This chapter explains the physical states of matter and the behaviour of gases and liquids using molecular interactions and kinetic theory.

properties: Definite volume but no fixed shape

boyles_law.statement: Pressure is inversely proportional to volume at constant temperature

charles_law.statement: Volume is directly proportional to temperature at constant pressure

avogadros_law.statement: Equal volumes of gases at same temperature and pressure contain equal number of molecules

ideal_gas_equation.significance: Combines all gas laws into a single equation

vapour_pressure.definition: Pressure exerted by vapour in equilibrium with liquid

boiling_point.definition: Temperature at which vapour pressure equals atmospheric pressure

chapters.one_liner: States of matter depend on how particles move and interact.

chapters.introduction: This chapter deals with energy changes accompanying physical and chemical processes and establishes quantitative relationships.

state_functions.definition: Properties that depend only on state, not path

hess_law.statement: Total enthalpy change is independent of path

chapters.one_liner: Thermodynamics decides whether a reaction can happen.

chapters.introduction: This chapter explains the state in which opposing processes occur at equal rates, covering both chemical and ionic equilibrium.

chemical_equilibrium.definition: State where forward and reverse reactions occur at equal rates

reversible_reaction.definition: Reaction that can proceed in both forward and backward directions

law_of_mass_action.statement: Rate of reaction is proportional to product of active masses of reactants

equilibrium_constant.definition: Ratio of product concentrations to reactant concentrations at equilibrium

le_chateliers_principle.statement: A system at equilibrium adjusts to counteract applied changes

acids_and_bases.arrhenius_concept: Acid produces H+, base produces OH−
acids_and_bases.bronsted_lowry_concept: Acid donates proton, base accepts proton

buffer_solutions.definition: Solution that resists change in pH

solubility_product.definition: Product of ion concentrations in saturated solution

chapters.one_liner: Equilibrium is balance, not inactivity.

chapters.introduction: This chapter deals with reactions involving transfer of electrons and changes in oxidation states.

oxidation.definition: Loss of electrons or increase in oxidation number

reduction.definition: Gain of electrons or decrease in oxidation number

oxidation_number.definition: Charge assigned to an atom assuming complete electron transfer
rules: Free element has oxidation number zero

redox_reaction.definition: Reaction involving both oxidation and reduction

chapters.one_liner: Redox reactions drive energy and life itself.

chapters.introduction: This chapter discusses the unique position of hydrogen in the periodic table and its preparation, properties, and compounds.

preparation_of_hydrogen.laboratory_method: Reaction of zinc with dilute acids

hydrides.definition: Compounds of hydrogen with other elements

chapters.one_liner: Hydrogen connects chemistry with life and energy.

chapters.introduction: This chapter studies alkali and alkaline earth metals, their properties, trends, and important compounds.
chapters.one_liner: s-Block elements define reactivity trends in chemistry.

chapters.introduction: This chapter studies the elements of Groups 13 and 14 of the periodic table, focusing on their occurrence, properties, and important compounds.

trend_overview: Increase in non-metallic character across period
Increase in metallic character down the group

boron.anomalous_behaviour: Small size and high ionisation enthalpy

chapters.one_liner: p-Block elements bridge metals and non-metals in chemistry.

chapters.chapter_name: Organic Chemistry – Basic Principles and Techniques
chapters.introduction: This chapter introduces organic chemistry, focusing on the structure, classification, and methods used to study organic compounds.

organic_compounds.definition: Compounds of carbon containing covalent bonds

functional_groups.definition: Atom or group of atoms responsible for characteristic reactions

homologous_series.definition: Series of compounds with similar chemical properties

isomerism.definition: Same molecular formula but different structures

chapters.one_liner: Organic chemistry starts with understanding structure before reactions.

chapters.introduction: This chapter introduces hydrocarbons—organic compounds containing only carbon and hydrogen—and explains their classification, preparation, properties, and reactions.

alkenes.definition: Unsaturated hydrocarbons with one double bond

alkynes.definition: Unsaturated hydrocarbons with one triple bond

aromatic_hydrocarbons.definition: Planar cyclic hydrocarbons with delocalised π-electrons

chapters.one_liner: Hydrocarbons are the backbone of organic chemistry and fuels.

chapters.introduction: This chapter studies chemical processes occurring in the environment and the impact of human activities on air, water, and soil.

atmospheric_pollution.definition: Contamination of air by harmful substances

acid_rain.formation: Reaction of SO2 and NO2 with water

greenhouse_effect.definition: Trapping of heat by greenhouse gases

green_chemistry.definition: Design of chemical processes to reduce hazardous substances

chapters.one_liner: Environmental chemistry connects chemical knowledge with responsibility.

chapters.introduction: This chapter introduces biology as the science of life and explains the characteristics of living organisms, biodiversity, and the need for classification.

metabolism.definition: Sum total of all chemical reactions occurring in an organism

biodiversity.definition: Variety of life forms on Earth

taxonomy.definition: Science of identification, nomenclature, and classification

chapters.one_liner: Biology begins by identifying, naming, and understanding life.

chapters.introduction: This chapter explains how organisms are classified into groups based on similarities, differences, and evolutionary relationships.
chapters.one_liner: Classification brings order to biological diversity.

chapters.introduction: This chapter deals with the classification of plants based on their structure, reproductive organs, and life cycles.
chapters.one_liner: Plant evolution shows a clear march towards complexity.

chapters.introduction: This chapter deals with the classification of animals based on levels of organisation, symmetry, germ layers, body cavity, and evolutionary relationships.
chapters.one_liner: Animal classification reflects evolutionary complexity.

chapters.introduction: This chapter studies the external structure of flowering plants and the modifications of different plant organs.
chapters.one_liner: Morphology explains how plant form supports function.

chapters.introduction: This chapter deals with the internal structure of plants and the organisation of tissues.
chapters.one_liner: Anatomy reveals how plant tissues work together internally.

chapters.introduction: This chapter explains how animal tissues are organised to form organs and organ systems, using examples of representative animals.
chapters.one_liner: Organisation of tissues defines efficiency of animal life.

chapters.introduction: This chapter introduces the cell as the basic structural and functional unit of life.

statements: All living organisms are composed of cells
Cell is the basic unit of life
New cells arise from pre-existing cells

chapters.one_liner: Cells are microscopic units carrying macroscopic life.

chapters.introduction: This chapter explains the chemical substances that form the basis of life and cellular functions.

proteins.structure: Amino acids linked by peptide bonds

chapters.one_liner: Biomolecules are the chemistry behind life.

chapters.introduction: This chapter explains how cells grow, replicate their genetic material, and divide to form new cells, ensuring growth, repair, and reproduction.

cell_cycle.definition: Sequence of events through which a cell passes from one division to the next

interphase.significance: Most active phase of the cell

mitosis.definition: Equational division resulting in two identical daughter cells

meiosis.definition: Reduction division producing four haploid cells

chapters.one_liner: Cell division sustains life across generations.

chapters.introduction: This chapter explains how water, minerals, and food are transported within plants.

transport_of_water.transpiration_pull: Major driving force for ascent of sap

transpiration.definition: Loss of water vapour from aerial parts of plant

chapters.one_liner: Efficient transport keeps plants alive and growing.

chapters.introduction: This chapter discusses the essential mineral elements required by plants and their roles.

criteria: Cannot be replaced by another element

chapters.one_liner: Mineral nutrition fuels plant metabolism and productivity.

chapters.introduction: This chapter explains the process by which green plants convert light energy into chemical energy, forming the basis of life on Earth.

photosynthesis.definition: Process by which green plants synthesise food using CO2, water, and sunlight in presence of chlorophyll

chapters.one_liner: Photosynthesis converts sunlight into life-sustaining energy.

chapters.introduction: This chapter explains how plants release energy from food through oxidation processes essential for growth and maintenance.

respiration.definition: Breakdown of organic compounds to release energy

respiratory_quotient.definition: Ratio of CO2 evolved to O2 consumed

chapters.one_liner: Respiration releases the energy locked in food.

chapters.introduction: This chapter studies growth patterns, phases, and the role of plant hormones in development.

plant_growth.definition: Irreversible increase in size and mass

photoperiodism.definition: Response of plants to day length

vernalisation.definition: Requirement of low temperature for flowering

chapters.one_liner: Plant development is controlled by growth regulators and environment.

chapters.introduction: This chapter explains the human digestive system, the process of digestion, and absorption of nutrients.

digestion.fats: Broken down into fatty acids and glycerol

chapters.one_liner: Digestion converts food into absorbable nutrients.

chapters.introduction: This chapter explains the mechanism of breathing and exchange of oxygen and carbon dioxide in humans.
chapters.one_liner: Breathing supplies oxygen for cellular respiration.

chapters.introduction: This chapter explains blood, lymph, and the circulatory system responsible for transport in humans.
chapters.one_liner: Circulation keeps every cell supplied and alive.

chapters.introduction: This chapter explains how metabolic waste products are removed from the human body to maintain internal balance.

nephron.definition: Structural and functional unit of kidney

osmoregulation.definition: Maintenance of water and salt balance

chapters.one_liner: Excretion maintains chemical balance inside the body.

chapters.introduction: This chapter explains how humans and animals move using muscles, bones, and joints.
chapters.one_liner: Movement is the visible expression of muscular activity.

chapters.introduction: This chapter explains how the nervous system controls and coordinates body activities through electrical and chemical signals.

neuron.definition: Structural and functional unit of nervous system

chapters.one_liner: Neural control ensures rapid and precise coordination.

chapters.introduction: This chapter explains how hormones regulate and coordinate physiological processes in the body through the endocrine system.

endocrine_system.definition: System of ductless glands that secrete hormones directly into the bloodstream

hypothalamus.role: Link between nervous and endocrine systems

feedback_mechanism.definition: Regulatory mechanism to maintain hormone levels

chapters.one_liner: Chemical coordination ensures long-term regulation and balance.
